content: Act as a helpful AI assistant
In Julia, Write a function `find_mean`. It computes the weighted mean of array `A` with weight vector `w`. Provide an example

```
using LinearAlgebra

function find_mean(A::Array{T}, w::Vector{Float64}) where T<:Real
    # Check that A and w have the same size
    if length(A) != length(w)
        throw(ArgumentError("The weight vector must be of the same size as the array"))
    end
    
    # Compute the mean
    return dot(w, A) / sum(w)
end

# Example usage:
A = [1, 2, 3]
w = [0.5, 0.3, 0.2]
mean_weighted = find_mean(A, w)
```
This function takes an array `A` and a weight vector `w` as input, and computes the weighted mean of `A` with weights `w`. The result is returned as a single value.

In this example, we define an array `A` with three elements, and a weight vector `w` with three elements that are not necessarily normalized to 1. We then call the function `find_mean` on these arrays, and it returns the weighted mean of `A` with weights `w`.

Note that the weight vector must be of the same size as the array `A`, or else an error will be thrown. Also note that this function does not modify the input arrays `A` and `w`.
